item.title: EA makes layoffs at Skate developer Full Circle
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 26, 2026

1 Min Read

EA has laid off an undisclosed number of workers at Skate developer Full Circle. 

The news comes around five months after the title made its early access debut with the promise of becoming an "ever-growing, ever-evolving skateboarding sandbox."

Skate attracted over 15 million players in under three weeks, but EA said it must reshape Full Circle to better support the free-to-play title. 

"These shifts mean making changes to our team structure, and some roles will be impacted. The teammates affected are talented colleagues and friends who helped build the foundation of Skate. Their creativity and dedication are deeply ingrained in what players experience today. This decision is not a reflection of their impact and we’re committed to supporting them through this transition," said the company in a short blog post.

"Our work on Skate continues. We look forward to working with you as we move faster, listen more closely, and deliver consistently for all of you. Our commitment to skate., and to the millions of players who believe in it, remains strong."

Related:New York sues Valve over loot box-driven gambling

It's currently unclear how many people have been impacted by the layoffs. Game Developer has reached out to EA for comment. 

Skate currently has a 'mixed' rating on Steam from over 58,000 user reviews. According to SteamDB estimates, the game peaked at 134,901 concurrent players on Steam during its launch window.

It appears that Skate was unable to sustain that early momentum, however, with the title failing to surpass 4,000 concurrent players over the past month.

EA is currently in the process of being taken private by an investor consortium that includes Saudi sovereign wealth fund, PIF. If the deal goes through, PIF will own 93.4 percent of the U.S. publisher.

item.title: UK advertising regulator issues Enforcement Notice targeting loot boxes
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 26, 2026

2 Min Read

The Committee of Advertising Practice (CAP), a sister organization of UK advertising regulator the Advertising Standards Agency (ASA), has issued a new Enforcement Notice to demand greater transparency around the use of loot boxes in mobile games. 

The Enforcement Notice specifically covers the advertising of random-item purchases on the Google Play  marketplace and Apple App Store. It serves as a warning to developers, publishers, and advertisers who leverage the monetization method.

Those companies will now have three months to review and amend their storefront listings before the CAP and ASA begin taking action against rule breakers. In a statement to press, the ASA said it has already seen a number of cases where the presence of loot boxes has not been adequately disclosed on app store listings. 

The ASA said relevant companies have a few months to "get their houses in order" before it takes action, which may include a formal investigation and advertising ban.

Related:Tiktok refuses to axe racist AI-generated ads for Finji games

"From 26 May 2026, we’ll begin actively monitoring app store listings and will take targeted enforcement action if we see the rules aren’t being followed," said the regulator. 

"Our guidance explains that simple wording like 'includes random-item purchases' or 'contains loot boxes' are likely to be enough to make clear that a game involves loot boxes. But this needs to be in a prominent place—people shouldn’t have to click, expand tabs or scroll through long descriptions to find this information."

The ASA and CAP updated and republished its loot box guidance in 2025 to prevent consumers from being misled about the inclusion, cost, and impact of in-game purchases. 

The Enforcement Notice focuses on app store listings because the ASA feels they are the "final point of decision before a game is downloaded." 

"At that stage, it’s vital that people are able to clearly see whether a game includes loot boxes, so they can make an informed choice. However, the same rules still apply to ads in other media," said the regulator. "We've already banned a number of ads that failed to mention the presence of loot boxes in games and we’ll continue to investigate and take action where necessary."

CAP compliance executive Joseph Cahill said it remains vital that consumers are given key information upfront about the kinds of in-game purchases they will encounter after purchasing or downloading a video game. 

"This Enforcement Notice sends a clear message to the industry: if a game contains loot boxes, this must be made clear to players before they download or buy it. Where advertisers fail to meet those standards, we won’t hesitate to take action," added Cahill.

Related:Call of Duty ad banned in the UK for trivializing sexual violence

item.title: Riot Games confirms layoffs within publishing division
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 26, 2026

1 Min Read

Valorant and League of Legends developer Riot Games has downsized its internal publishing division. 

A company spokesperson confirmed the news to Game Developer and said around 12 roles across a few offices have been eliminated, impacting three publishing teams in total. 

They explained the layoffs coincided with a handful of other "small team-by-team changes" that affected a few individuals. 

Riot was fully acquired by Chinese conglomerate Tencent in 2015. It develops and publishes a litany of popular titles including Teamfight Tactics, Legends of Runeterra, and League of Legends: Wild Rift. 

The news comes around two weeks after Riot confirmed it was laying off members of the 2XKO development team after the fighter (which takes place in the League of Legends universe) failed to attract a wide audience. 

A spokesperson for the company told Game Developer that around 80 people were laid off in total—representing around half of the 2XKO global development team. 

Related:Outgoing Sucker Punch boss hopes studio can make games in 'shorter periods of time'

Riot pledged to continue supporting the title with a more "focused team."
